As we are using powerfull servers :-O we are facing this issue. This is fixing this behaviour. We can discuss minimal workers, just let me know and I will change. But 32 is OK i think.
Why not 64? Are there two interfaces being used? Let's also add an inline comment as to why this has been.
needs release note?

Did you check bugreport in commit message for bind9 ? Citation from bugreport : 

https://kb.isc.org/docs/aa-00716 is also helpful:
"""
BIND 9.9.0 introduced multiple UDP listeners to improve performance, which means that in a multi-threaded BIND installation, there are effectively more sockets being monitored for client-side queries. If you are also listening on multiple interfaces (real or virtual), this might mean that # interfaces x # UDP listeners exceeds 64. The outcome of this is that on a busy server (particularly a busy recursive server that is also opening connections to make iterative queries of authoritative servers), the default number of FD events is already too small.
"""

There are two options:
a) rebuild with a higher limit
b) reduce the number of UDP listeners

(b) is achieved with the -U command line option:

       -U #listeners
           Use #listeners worker threads to listen for incoming UDP packets on each address. If not specified, named will calculate a default value based on the number of detected CPUs: 1 for 1 CPU, and
           the number of detected CPUs minus one for machines with more than 1 CPU. This cannot be increased to a value higher than the number of CPUs. If -n has been set to a higher value than the number
           of detected CPUs, then -U may be increased as high as that value, but no higher. On Windows, the number of UDP listeners is hardwired to 1 and this option has no effect.

88 processors is probably not very common, and according to the above kb link, having more than 32 listeners might not increase performance at all. Could MAAS perhaps limit the number of listeners on such machines via this parameter? Notice it's this value per address.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
This master version is an "upport" of the stable/train version.

The main implication is that this hasn't been tested on a master env yet.

I guess my concern would be, what happens if the user forgets / doesn't run this step? OVN just doesn't get upgraded? Does that cause other problems for us?

I'm familiar with the issue you're addressing, and ovn_controller not being able to connect to northd if the versions mismatch occurs. It happens to users even during overcloud deploy outside of updates if they are using tag: 16.x instead of specific z-streams. But it would be nice if we could somehow better handle this during the update run process itself. Purely from a user-experience perspective.

Even if we did something like record a Ansible fact containing the current version of northd and ovn_controller and block updates to OVN based on those facts. I guess it would break our --limit Controller though if we needed to go and upgrade the Compute ovn_controller.

I don't have a concrete solution that I would say is better than this proposal. So I personally wont object to the change. Just thought I would throw in a different perspective and opinion for consideration.

> But it would be nice if we could somehow better handle this during the update run process itself. Purely from a user-experience perspective.

Totally agree on this, but given how triple revolves around the idea that *a* server is *a* role, we have a very hard time to model anything around a distributed service like OVN with hard constraint about how its architecture is updated.

When updating the controller, trying to delegate a task that all compute to update the ovn_controller would just be unexpected long and fragile (and would break the Role barrier).

When updating the OSP controller, trying to block any request from the ovn_controller until they are updated on the computes would create a control plane issue during update (no new VMs can be created), which is not acceptable.

> I guess my concern would be, what happens if the user forgets / doesn't run this > step? OVN just doesn't get upgraded? Does that cause other problems for us?

If the user forget, then two things can happen:
 1. nothing: some versions of OVN manage to work just fine while being updated starting with ovn-northd;
 2. data plane and control plane total failure: all ping to FIP attached to VMs are broken and no new VMs can be trigger, this is solved by updating ovn_controller on each server belonging to the Compute Role.

The impact in 2. is pretty dramatic, but then the solution is to run the new command and everything will recover very quickly, so now at least we have an easy way to recover instantaneously, while before we had only "run the update on all compute ASAP"

Thinking about this some... Why do we need the ISO/PXEboot installer to run both the RT and STD versions of the kernel? For bootstrapping a system (i.e. installing ostree and running the kickstarts that will select an installed runtime kernel based on the traits), can't we just stick with the std kernel for all types?

cf. our decision on https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/799111 and let's focus on https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/714999 (I need to revive it)

Why not? How it differs from any another cinder-backed glance config? It works perfect at least at 3 known to me clouds (victoria, xena, yoga). If storage system supports snapshots and cinder image cache is enabled volumes creates in seconds.
Totally agree with you! I just wanted to propose Cinder backend for Glance in the next k-a improvement. And it's cool that you're already working on it!

We had some issues with Glance with Cinder backed, let me find our notes. Image-Volume cache is independent on Glance backend. Glance+NFS and Cinder+FC works fine. Glance backend works only first image usage, next one works via FC clone.

Since 'tripleo_role' tag is now added in tags I think this method to find the existing ports will not work with this change in case the system was updated/upgraded?

I guess it makes sense to set the tripleo_role tag on these ports as well, but I think we need to use a tags list without the 'tripleo_role' tag here, at-least for one release to ensure we don't end up with duplicate ports.

If the api call specify just a subset of tags the port won't be excluded, but if the API call sepecify tag 'tripleo_role' while ports don't have this tag the port will be excluded in result.

The 'name' from 'server_resource_names' (uniq hostname) and the tag 'tripleo_stack_name=****' is enough to get the correct result. This is why 
tripleo_role tag was never added for the ovn_mac_address ports.

would it be smart to manage the endpoint a bit?

ex: when you reboot the ""master keepalived"" server, the FIP will go to the next slave one, the mysql will be down. it will create a few traceback on differents services.
when it comes back the FIP will move back to the original server, creating a few more trace there.. then the musql primary will come back. and i think it will create a few more there also.

When i do reboot the server i usualy disable the primary mysql server on the second keepalived server and disable keepalived on the primary one so it doesn't start on boot.

I also usually move the router active interface around so i don't have a huge downtime on tenant networks. it depends how many network runs but past 100-150 it can take quite a long time (10-15-30min) to recover all the networks keepalived off the routers.
I guess network weren't taken into account here at all, as assumption about standalone net nodes were made. But these are really valid comments.
we also missing draining all backends for haproxy which would be awesome thing to do

nit: you can do this far simpler in Python 3

  except libvirt.libvirtError as ex:
       errcode = ex.get_error_code()
       if errcode == libvirt.VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR:
           errmsg = ex.get_error_message()
           if (errmsg != 'internal error: migration was active, '
                         'but no RAM info was set'):
               raise

I think the only advantage to doing what you're doing is that if any of the code in the exception handler throws its own exception, we'll still raise the original exception. However, I'm not certain about this and in this case it wouldn't matter since none of this should cause an exception.

Maybe I'm missing something but I put the save_and_reraise_exception() so that it will reraise if errcode != libvirt.VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR. And I thought that even with Python 3, we still have to use save_and_reraise_exception() in order to not lose the exception if there's an eventlet thread switch.

Or are you saying there is no eventlet switchable code in the block? (I guess there isn't.) In that case, you would prefer the following?

  except libvirt.libvirtError as ex:

Did you look into putting container_existence_skip_cache_pct into [DEFAULT]? That passing around the final app looks just a bit too dangerous. Worse, the code silently ignores any issues by catching AttributeError. So, why not just remove all of that?

> Did you look into putting container_existence_skip_cache_pct into [DEFAULT]? That passing around the final app looks just a bit too dangerous.

What would the idea be? Have every middleware extract that themselves and pass it as part of get_container_info? Sounds like a lot of extra churn and increased bug surface area.

> Worse, the code silently ignores any issues by catching AttributeError. So, why not just remove all of that?

It's a feature, not a bug -- in case other (third party) middlewares are composed the way s3api and versioned_writes are (so the inner filter doesn't have the final app reference). I don't think that's common, but want to be robust to it.

FWIW, some of the old patchsets of https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/821921 let the AttributeError buddle out -- see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/821921/3/swift/proxy/controllers/base.py for example.

Maybe there should be some configurability for middleware developers? OTOH, if they're that concerned about their get-info calls, they could always hack up the proxy server themselves. *shrug*
Thanks for the fixups; sorry I hadn't gotten to them! LGTM -- do we want to let it run in prod for a bit before merging, or just go for it?

It doesn't seem to be necessary to update the CORS rules on every log upload. Once set, the rules will be valid for the future and apply to the whole bucket.

For context: https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul-jobs/+/790050 adds support for configuring log retention on upload and we are using this already in our deployment.

However, in our Zuul configuration of the S3 upload role we had to set `zuul_log_delete_after_days` to 0 as log uploads will sometimes fail if there are too many requests that try to update the lifecycle policy. I think the same will be true for the CORS rules. (we configure the bucket lifecycle policy when we initially created the bucket).

I'd propose to rebase this change on 790050 and only configure the CORS rules when `create_bucket` is set to True.

wfm. I'm not too keen on the extra API requests on every upload for something that's probably not changing very often, but I think it's better to be consistent here.

I'll add a comment to 790050

Our log roles are expected to handle the case where the container is already created and correct settings where necessary, so we should not perform this only on container creation.  It is unfortunate that AWS can't handle collisions like that.  Other log upload roles do this on every upload without incident (it should be a no-op).

It seems like the best solution would be to perform a GET of the CORS rules and then update them if they are not correct.  Maybe that's a solution for the lifecycle change too?

tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/.message:
I think this looks good and should work during the overcloud deployment. But if the user is just using `openstack tripleo container image prepare -e containers-prepare-parameter.yaml` then we wouldn't have a roles_data list to refer to here and it would default to an empty list:
https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_container_image_prepare.py#L52

So, we probably need a parser to allow users to provide a roles_data.yaml file as input to the command?
https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/master/tripleoclient/v2/tripleo_container_image.py#L58

the container image prepare command accepts path for roles_data.yaml so this roles_data should get the list of default roles. In case the deployment is using a customized role then the role file should be passed but that is not a new requirement but what we've required since this image prepare process was introduced.

https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/master/tripleoclient/v1/container_image.py#L516-L522

The line you pointed is for image *build*, though we might need something trigger the build process for all versions.

I think to avoid any chances of something breaking in the future, we can just delete the {role}ContainerImagePrepare object at this point. Since we have now configured the tmp_env['parameter_defaults'['ContainerImagePrepare']. If we leave it, then we end up sending bot ComputeContainerImagePrepare and also ContainerImagePrepare. This doesn't cause any problems today, but to minimise the chances of mistakes and confusion in the future, we can do something like this on line 161:

```
del tmp_env['parameter_defaults'[role_param]
```

These needs to be merged with other env {{role.name}}Parameters. Though it would have been good to provide parameter_merge_strategy in this environment, it would work with the recent changes we've done in heat to use existing merge strategy[1]


[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.j2.yaml

src/charm.py.message: This set of events and interface class is to make it as neat as possible for the charm to react to new fernet key distribution.  It checks the peer data changed hook and if it detects updated fernet keys, it triggers the custom event.  Ensures the charm class doesn't need to worry about the app data, and just focus on the higher level things.

Ah good idea.  I originally was thinking that the json string could change without the data changing (eg. if the keys changed order), but yeah I guess this is only written to after a key rotation, so it will only ever change if it's been updated.

As the value on the interface is JSON encoded as a string I'd be very tempted to skip all of the loading above and just checksum the string value - if the checksum is different then there are new keys to deal with!
We don't need to write the keys if this is the same charm that triggered the event, but not sure how to check if it's the same charm that triggered the event...
TODO: sort out a method of periodically triggering this that doesn't rely on update-status... leaning toward an undercloud k8s cronjob.
Here's a thought: how heavy are k8s cronjobs?  Is it a waste of resources to have a CronJob for every keystone unit, in addition to the existing keystone pod and juju sidecar pod?

This method (launching a separate process here, see heartbeat.py for how it sends a custom event back to the charm) is based on prior art at https://github.com/canonical/observability-libs/blob/main/lib/charms/observability_libs/v0/metrics_endpoint_discovery.py

I think we have some design issues with this approach that need to be discussed and addressed.
Let's not merge this as is.

designate/conf/mdns.py.message:
So this means that users cannot define which records are available is which view. They have to go to an operator to push out configuration changes to every instances to change the regex.
It also seems like a rough user experience to properly define the regex strings, especially when you add IPv6 addresses.
These could also get very complicated and log with some CIDRs.

Maybe a better solution would be to just check if it is within a set of subnets? e.g. all IPs within 10.0.0.0/8 subnets are allowed or something like that. This could be a list of subnets (both IPv4 and IPv6), or maybe even simpler a flag to allow only non-private IPs on the "external" DNS server?
i dont understand fully, but in this case the regex define the records that should be included when the tsig key is sent, the regex should be easy to write and test there is online sites for that

designate/mdns/handler.py.message: Try to avoid \, better to just wrap the if statement in ().
maybe return bool(match) would be simpler here.

I'm not a huge fan of running a regex on every AAAA/A record in a zone. This seems hugely inefficient.
It seems like a better approach might have been to extend the recordset "records" to tag to optionally tag the view name. That way we should use a simple database filter to produce the right list.
Ideally that would be paired with a view management API for zones that allows the definition of the CIDRs for each named view.

it was done like this to minimize the changes to records / zone tables
if we want to tag the records as external/internal (or any view ) that should depend on some criteria 
like Neutron network (internal/external(this disable designate integrations)) so its complicated if we do it other than this way

You could do something like
> IPv4Address(vm_ip) in IPv4Network(subnet['cidr'])
or maybe something like this using the IPy module
> from IPy import IP
> if IP(ip_address).iptype() != 'PRIVATE':
Might be able to do the same with the inbuilt IP module as well.

If the inbuilt python library can't do something neat like IPy we could probably just use IPy. A few other OpenStack projects uses it.

deployment/cinder/cinder-backend-nfs-pup.message: if we are going to refactor this out into it's own template, then I wonder if this should work like all the other storage templates, and this should default to true. The way to enable the backend ought to be by just the right mapping in the resource_registry, not the resource_registry *and* a parameter.

Agreed , thanks for bringing this up.
Done!.

Reopening to continue the discussion. I was the one who suggested Manoj work on this, and the motivation (as I state in another comment) is limited to cleaning up the cinder-volume-contain-puppet.yaml file by moving the NFS (and also RBD) backend parameters into their own THT. Having them all in one file is a very old legacy thing, and over time the file became messy and unwieldy.

That said, I want to retain the legacy behavior and not inadvertently disrupt things when someone does an update. To do that, I proposed the CinderBackendNfs tripleo service default to the new THT (not make it OS::Heat::None), and leave CinderEnableNfsBackend defaulting to false.

The goal is to ensure doing an update doesn't inadvertently flip the NFS backend on/off, or vice versa.

Although the general model for cinder backend templates would suggest this default value, it should be False in this template in order to avoid problems on upgrades. The legacy behavior, where NFS didn't have its own dedicated template, defaulted CinderEnableNfsBackend to false, and users had to manually override the setting to enable the backend. We should keep the same default value (false) in order to retain the legacy behavior so there are no surprises.

As we discussed on irc, this patch should retain the same tripleo::XXX hiera variables and not switch to cinder:XXX variable names. This will ensure the new THT will continue to work with the existing puppet-tripleo manifests.

It may be worth changing both THT and puppet-tripleo to use cinder::XXX variables (unfortunately, the cinder backends aren't consistent), but that should be handled by separate patches.

Considering the fact that there is a chance for someone using this file, reverted this change in the latest patch.

I modified this env file along with sample-env-generator/storage.yaml to resolve sample-env-generator errors in CI.

'CinderEnableIscsiBackend' is not part of the new NFS template, it can be removed from this env file as NFS backend configuration is no longer done in cinder-volume-container-puppet.yaml

I think it is ok to have default iscsi(lvm) backend enabled along with NFS unless user wants to disable it explicitly. (same is the case with all other cinder backends)

Moreover this env file is outdated, latest one in use is https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/environments/cinder-nfs-config.yaml.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
OSBS issues aside, there's the problem spelled out in [1] where ARGs can either be defined:
- before the FROM line and only be available in the FROM line, or
- after the FROM line and be available during the actual build

Having both TRIPLEO_ANSIBLE_REQ (meant to be used at build time) and ANSIBLE_RUNNER_IMAGE (meant to be used in the FROM line) without a mechanism to insert each in a different places within the Dockerfile was incompatible with the Dockerfile reference[2].

I don't mean this as a correction, just piling on one more reason why we need this change, and why we would need it even if OSBS followed standards 100%.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/858508
[2] https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/builder/#understand-how-arg-and-from-interact

before removing it here, please make sure this depends on removing its references in other repos? https://codesearch.opendev.org/?q=ANSIBLE_RUNNER_IMAGE&i=nope&literal=nope&files=&excludeFiles=&repos=

(note: this is still iptables for the jobs running here)
ip saddr 104.239.144.76 tcp dport 19885  counter packets 4 bytes 240 accept

As a side note, it seems the current rules set in openstack-INPUT are weaker:
meta l4proto tcp ct state new tcp dport 19885 counter packets 0 bytes 0 accept

So, as I thought, it was working "by chance" with the nftables based firewall, because of the "established/related" connections being accepted.

Also: with iptables, we don't see any drop related to that console port, because it's actually dropping (and logging) only the NEW packets. We're seeing SYN in nftables logs, because it's dropping *all* packets that don't match any rule.

<<< I tried to replicate this by booting this image in a VM, setting up tripleo-repos, and updating only the kernel. It updated the kernel from 5.14.0-160 to 5.14.0-165 and the reboot worked, both in UEFI and Bios boot mode. Maybe there was an interim kernel version (5.14.0-163?) which had an issue.

@Steve AFAIU issue is not specific to kernel but the process, i.e virt-customize in the case we seeing it in CI, i think it should reproduce if you take the an overcloud image(should have some old kernel then the one latest available in repos) and update that image via virt-customize and boot the updated image.

<< I think we need a dedicated day-2 playbook for updating the kernel so any extra post-install file changing can be done. How is day-2 package updates done currently?
I am not sure how it's done currently but i assume it's generic dnf update that you have done in your tests and that should be fine if new kernels are good enough.

> @Steve btw do you know why updating kernel in image making those non bootable

I tried to replicate this by booting this image in a VM, setting up tripleo-repos, and updating only the kernel. It updated the kernel from 5.14.0-160 to 5.14.0-165 and the reboot worked, both in UEFI and Bios boot mode. Maybe there was an interim kernel version (5.14.0-163?) which had an issue.

However, UEFI boot booted with 5.14.0-160 because /boot/efi/EFI/centos/grubenv was stale compared to /boot/grub2/grubenv.

I think we need a dedicated day-2 playbook for updating the kernel so any extra post-install file changing can be done. How is day-2 package updates done currently?

Jobs should definitely be run with the kernel that is built into the overcloud image to be valid. The link Marios posted uses --disablerepo="*". Since we only want to install packages in gating-repo. That might be a more general solution than --exclude=kernel*

I recalled we have seen issues if we do --disablerepo='*' it was that way in past but that option dropped with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/+/446129, but that time i think we used to run update in upgrade jobs and there were more chances to hit it. Although it's rare for that case to trigger but can happen.

passing rpm names to update command can work though but using artg_rdo_packages can be trickier due to subpackages having different namings. but what we do in modify-image role[1] can be used

[1] https://github.com/openstack/ansible-role-tripleo-modify-image/blob/master/templates/yum_update.sh.j2#L30


@Steve btw do you know why updating kernel in image making those non bootable, what i noticed kernel flags are not set correctly, but didn't got why? I think we have never seen this issue before atleast with CentOS7 and CentOS8-Stream?
We can do it in jobs this way but Not sure if we have this limitation documented somewhere?
You could even build an explicit list of packages to install from artg_rdo_packages etc, just like run_dlrn.sh.j2

neutron/common/ovn/hash_ring_manager.py.message:
I am not opposed by the current proposal but, I was wondering... Wouldn't be simpler to move the _clear_hash_ring() method to this class and add lock between it and _load_hash_ring() to prevent both methods from being called concurrently ?

.. mech_driver.py:

 def initialize():
     ...
     self._hash_ring_lock = threading.Event()
     self._hash_ring_lock.clear()
 
.. hash_ring_manager.py:

 # _hash_ring_lock passed via the class constructor

 def _clear_hash_ring():
     ...
     self._hash_ring_lock.set()
     
 def _load_hash_ring():
     self._hash_ring_lock.wait()
     ...

That won't prevent the clash between two Neutron servers. This is what is preventing this implementation. By default, if only one Neutron server is spawned, this situation should not happen because the table cleanup is executed before the API workers are spawned (and the node registers are created and the OVN events start coming, forcing the DB read).

But when server 1 is spawning the API workers and executing those consecutive SQL table reads (hundreds per second) and server 2 starts and tries to cleanup the table, is at this moment when we have the DB lock.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message: Nit: Sounds more like a warning
Well... because this is going to be retried in the next loop until the table cleanup is achieved, I prefer to keep it in INFO level, to avoid noise in the logs.

>> based on the commit - This changes removes the pins of jobs to those versions which will cause the jobs to run against the current zuul tenant default ansible (version 5) 

Want to crosscheck were we expecting to see V5 here now and not Ansible Version: 2.12.9?
I have added links for the zuul tenant default version in the commit message comment. I also have the same question from where Ansible Version: 2.12.9 is coming?

The version info that ansible reports is confusing and Zuul has had to do its best here. The `ansible` package which includes `ansible-core` and other useful collections had versions like 2.8.x, 2.9.x, 4.x, 5.x, and now 6.x. This is what Zuul installs into its ansible runtime environments for jobs. This is why we use those versions for specifying the runtime in the Zuul config. But when you ask ansible to report its version it reports the ansible-core version which is 2.8.x, 2.9.x, 2.10.x and so on. In this case ansible 5.x maps to ansible-core 2.12.x.

As for your package requirements they should be completely independent of this. This attribute describes the ansible version zuul should use to execute your test jobs. Then within that test job you can manage your package dependencies in a separate ansible install however you like.

I would advice against strictly managing this in your jobs. No one else is doing it, and it hasn't appeared to be necessary. Instead it creates this unnecessary headache when Zuul drops old versions. You should only set ansible-version in your zuul jobs if there is a strict requirement for that version in your jobs for some reason.

i don't have an answer for the where are we getting it from but it seems we have related pins in requirements.txt/test-requirements across tripleo repos eg [1][2] 

I think we should consider updating our pin to a supported version, rather than removing it altogether so we are using a version of ansible that the tripleo repos expect. 


[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/commit/7898061a317d38cee421e5d185538589ed274ac0/ansible-requirements.txt#L1

[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/commit/db8e72f9fc3ea4ff3dc9bb12d058543987c71c3d/test-ansible-requirements.txt#L5
